metadata.title: Stanford University
metadata.raw_text: At Stanford, our mission of discovery and learning is energized by a spirit of optimism and possibility that dates to our founding. Here you’ll find a place of intellectual expansiveness, wide-ranging perspectives, and freedom to explore new lines of thinking. Buzzing with ideas and innovation, approaching questions with openness and curiosity, pursuing excellence in all we do – this is Stanford. Driving discoveries vital to our world, our health, and our intellectual life 6,699 Inventions created by federally funded Stanford research 3,029 U.S. patents based on federally funded Stanford research 400+ Start-up companies founded based on federally funded research at Stanford 350,000+ Jobs created by companies that started with federally funded Stanford research $94 Billion Private investment in start-up companies that grew out of federally funded Stanford research $11+ trillion Market value of the top 30 companies founded by Stanford alumni Providing student-athletes the opportunity to achieve excellence both in competition and in the classroom Home of Champions Stanford’s 137 NCAA championships are the most for any university, a product of an unrivaled culture of excellence and continued support from the campus community
metadata.text:
At Stanford, our mission of discovery and learning is energized by a spirit of optimism and possibility that dates to our founding. Here you’ll find a place of intellectual expansiveness, wide-ranging perspectives, and freedom to explore new lines of thinking. Buzzing with ideas and innovation, approaching questions with openness and curiosity, pursuing excellence in all we do – this is Stanford.
Driving discoveries vital to our world, our health, and our intellectual life
6,699 Inventions created by federally funded Stanford research
3,029 U.S. patents based on federally funded Stanford research
400+ Start-up companies founded based on federally funded research at Stanford
350,000+ Jobs created by companies that started with federally funded Stanford research
$94 Billion Private investment in start-up companies that grew out of federally funded Stanford research
$11+ trillion Market value of the top 30 companies founded by Stanford alumni
Providing student-athletes the opportunity to achieve excellence both in competition and in the classroom
Home of Champions
Stanford’s 137 NCAA championships are the most for any university, a product of an unrivaled culture of excellence and continued support from the campus community
metadata.excerpt: Our mission of discovery and learning is energized by a spirit of optimism and possibility that dates to our founding.

metadata.title: Academics
metadata.raw_text: Stanford students create and apply knowledge by thinking and doing, preparing for leadership in a rapidly changing world. Main Content Academics Undergraduate Studies Undergraduate Education Stanford Undergrad is your guide to undergraduate academics and opportunities run by the Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education. Majors Explore the 66 major fields of undergraduate study at Stanford. Undergraduate Facts & Figures Approximately 7,550 undergraduate students attend Stanford. Learn more about the undergraduate program and student body. Seven schools on one campus offer students boundless opportunities to pursue their passions and collaborate on solving complex global problems. Learn more about our seven schools Graduate Studies Office of the Vice Provost for Graduate Education The VPGE office works collaboratively across the University to ensure that every graduate student has the best possible education. Graduate Facts & Figures Today, 9,915 students are pursuing 18 distinct postbaccalaureate degrees in about 150 graduate programs in all seven of Stanford’s schools. Learn more about graduate studies at Stanford. Lifelong Learning From Pre-K to College Stanford offers a variety of educational and enrichment opportunities for young children through high schoolers and community college students. Offerings include STEM programs for all ages, classes for parents of infants to teens, an entire online high school, and internships. Professional Development Learn from our expert faculty as you grow your knowledge in your professional sphere or prepare to pivot into a new career. Learning for Exploration and Enrichment No matter where you live or work, Stanford offers learning opportunities that empower you to feed your curiosity, seek meaning, and engage wholeheartedly in the world.

metadata.title: Research
metadata.raw_text: World-Changing Discoveries Stanford’s robust and pioneering research ecosystem is supported by a long-standing partnership between universities and the federal government. Thousands of projects across campus and around the world drive discoveries in areas vital to our world, our health, and our intellectual life. Invented at Stanford: Antibody therapies that made cancer and autoimmune disease treatments possible Artificial organ prototypes and advancements in artificial hearts and other organ-support technologies Recombinant DNA technology that laid the foundation for the biotech industry Google’s page-rank algorithm that revolutionized searching the web Internet protocols (TCP/IP) that formed the backbone of the modern internet Microwave technology that made military radar detection, commercial air navigation, and satellite communications possible Neural networks and reinforcement learning, which laid the groundwork for the AI revolution
metadata.text:
World-Changing Discoveries
Stanford’s robust and pioneering research ecosystem is supported by a long-standing partnership between universities and the federal government. Thousands of projects across campus and around the world drive discoveries in areas vital to our world, our health, and our intellectual life.
Invented at Stanford:
- Antibody therapies that made cancer and autoimmune disease treatments possible
- Artificial organ prototypes and advancements in artificial hearts and other organ-support technologies
- Recombinant DNA technology that laid the foundation for the biotech industry
- Google’s page-rank algorithm that revolutionized searching the web
- Internet protocols (TCP/IP) that formed the backbone of the modern internet
- Microwave technology that made military radar detection, commercial air navigation, and satellite communications possible
- Neural networks and reinforcement learning, which laid the groundwork for the AI revolution
metadata.excerpt: Stanford research has a distinctive track record of developing life-changing treatments for disease, inventing revolutionary technologies, and unlocking new ways of understanding the world around us.

links.text: More Stanford research making a better world

organizations: Faculty Affairs Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement

metadata.title: Faculty Affairs Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement
metadata.raw_text: Faculty Affairs Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement About The Faculty Affairs division of the Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement is responsible for implementation of University policy regarding appointments and promotions, salary setting, leaves, endowed chair appointments, appeals, and other matters of an academic nature. Important Information Faculty Supplemental Compensation Faculty Supplemental Compensation Website  (SUNet ID protected) The Request for Approval Form and school approver contact list can be found on the site:  https://supcomp.stanford.edu/  . Online Harassment Resource: A new website  (SUNet ID protected) has been created that provides guidance, support, and resources for faculty and academic staff-teaching affected by toxic online behaviors such as insults, stalking, threats of bodily harm, and sexual harassment. Pay Transparency Law Compliance In this section, you will find guidelines and other information for Faculty and Academic Staff/Other Teaching Staff job postings as mandated under California’s Pay Transparency law (S.B. 1162), which went into effect January 1, 2023 and requires Stanford to include pay ranges for every job posted. General Guidelines for Compliance with California’s Pay Transparency Law Additional resources are available to faculty affairs officers located within the  internal pages  (SUNet ID protected) of this website.
metadata.text:
Faculty Affairs Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement
About
![Eye ball in magnifying glass](/sites/g/files/sbiybj23501/files/styles/medium/public/media/image/black_discovery_0.png?itok=6v9x_CqS)
The Faculty Affairs division of the Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement is responsible for implementation of University policy regarding appointments and promotions, salary setting, leaves, endowed chair appointments, appeals, and other matters of an academic nature.
Important Information
Faculty Supplemental Compensation
[Faculty Supplemental Compensation Website](https://supcomp.stanford.edu/) (SUNet ID protected)
The Request for Approval Form and school approver contact list can be found on the site: [https://supcomp.stanford.edu/](https://supcomp.stanford.edu/) .
Online Harassment Resource:
[A new website](https://onlineharassment-internal.stanford.edu/) (SUNet ID protected) has been created that provides guidance, support, and resources for faculty and academic staff-teaching affected by toxic online behaviors such as insults, stalking, threats of bodily harm, and sexual harassment.
Pay Transparency Law Compliance
In this section, you will find guidelines and other information for Faculty and Academic Staff/Other Teaching Staff job postings as mandated under California’s Pay Transparency law (S.B. 1162), which went into effect January 1, 2023 and requires Stanford to include pay ranges for every job posted.
[General Guidelines for Compliance with California’s Pay Transparency Law](https://drive.google.com/uc?export=download&id=1v412otw62VE3rueQPvyc038LAae7isnL)
Additional resources are available to faculty affairs officers located within the [internal pages](https://facultyaffairsinternal.sites.stanford.edu/faculty-affairs-internal-pages/general-guidelines-compliance-californias-pay-transparency-law) (SUNet ID protected) of this website.
metadata.source-hostname: Faculty Affairs Office of the Vice Provost for Faculty Advancement

classification.reasoning: The Faculty Senate is a governing body within an academic institution, and the content discusses proposals related to university speech policies, which fall under academic program governance.

metadata.title: Faculty Senate
metadata.raw_text: Faculty Senate Read the report from the ad hoc committee on university speech  here here On May 30, 2024 the Senate passed two of the proposals contained in the report with amendments:  SenD#8480  and  SenD#8481 . The Senate will take up the third proposal at a later date. The Senate met on November 20, 2025 The next Senate meeting will take place on January 22, 2026 beginning promptly at 3:15pm 58th Steering Committee of the Senate The Steering Committee (StC) of the Senate sets the Senate Agenda, confers degrees for the Summer, Autumn and Winter quarters, and serves at Administrative Sessions to the StC to review undergraduate and graduate programs on behalf of the Senate. StC members are elected each year by the Senate. This year's StC members are: Anna Grzymala-Busse, Chair (Political Science) Dustin Schroeder, Vice Chair (Geophysics, Electrical Engineering) Patricia Burchat (Physics) James Ferrell (Chemical and Systems Biology) Sarah Heilshorn (Materials Science and Engineering) Iván Marinovic (Graduate School of Education) Jisha Menon (Theater and Performance Studies) Richard Saller (Classics) Jenny Martinez (Provost, ex-officio) Bruce Clemens (Academic Secretary, ex-officio) Adrienne Emory (Associate Academic Secretary, Staff) 2025-26 Schedule of Meetings of Senate LVII The Senate meets biweekly during the academic year, usually in the Law School, room 180. Senators should be aware that if special meetings of the Senate need to be scheduled, which occurs infrequently, they will be scheduled on the intervening Thursdays. If you are a Stanford community member interested in attending a Senate meeting please contact Adrienne Emory at  aemory@stanford.edu .  Agendas and Minutes, as they become available, can be viewed by clicking on the links in the table below. AUTUMN QUARTER WINTER QUARTER SPRING QUARTER AUTUMN QUARTER  10/09/25 WINTER QUARTER 01/22/26 Agenda Minutes SPRING QUARTER 04/09/26 Agenda Minutes AUTUMN QUARTER  10/23/25 WINTER QUARTER 02/05/26 Agenda Minutes SPRING QUARTER 04/23/26 Agenda Minutes AUTUMN QUARTER  11/06/25 WINTER QUARTER 02/19/26 Agenda Minutes SPRING QUARTER 05/07/26 Agenda Minutes AUTUMN QUARTER  11/20/25 WINTER QUARTER 03/05/26 Agenda Minutes SPRING QUARTER 05/21/26 Annual Academic Council Meeting Agenda Minutes AUTUMN QUARTER WINTER QUARTER SPRING QUARTER 06/11/26 Agenda Minutes Administrative Sessions of the Steering Committee on Behalf of the Senate The Steering Committee (StC) holds administrative sessions as needed to hear routine or administrative matters that would otherwise come before the full Senate. This allows the Senate to spend more time on issues that need broader discussion and debate prior to action. All Senators are welcome to attend administrative sessions.
metadata.text:
Faculty Senate
Read the report from the ad hoc committee on university speech [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FpqzXqpQcg_4p-NYp_7SNQNcMdmaOUHT/view?usp=sharing)
On May 30, 2024 the Senate passed two of the proposals contained in the report with amendments: [SenD#8480](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GBTIN1XzSbFHJAGlseo3lo7iECugAXpA/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=104682877837992011680&rtpof=true&sd=true) and [SenD#8481](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KvNbSoqmW2Ws406eLgYU3eYVvXiZFx8q/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=104682877837992011680&rtpof=true&sd=true). The Senate will take up the third proposal at a later date.
The Senate met on November 20, 2025
The next Senate meeting will take place on January 22, 2026 beginning promptly at 3:15pm
58th Steering Committee of the Senate
The Steering Committee (StC) of the Senate sets the Senate Agenda, confers degrees for the Summer, Autumn and Winter quarters, and serves at Administrative Sessions to the StC to review undergraduate and graduate programs on behalf of the Senate. StC members are elected each year by the Senate. This year's StC members are:
Anna Grzymala-Busse, Chair (Political Science)
Dustin Schroeder, Vice Chair (Geophysics, Electrical Engineering)
Patricia Burchat (Physics)
James Ferrell (Chemical and Systems Biology)
Sarah Heilshorn (Materials Science and Engineering)
Iván Marinovic (Graduate School of Education)
Jisha Menon (Theater and Performance Studies)
Richard Saller (Classics)
Jenny Martinez (Provost, ex-officio)
Bruce Clemens (Academic Secretary, ex-officio)
Adrienne Emory (Associate Academic Secretary, Staff)
2025-26 Schedule of Meetings of Senate LVII
The Senate meets biweekly during the academic year, usually in the Law School, room 180. Senators should be aware that if special meetings of the Senate need to be scheduled, which occurs infrequently, they will be scheduled on the intervening Thursdays.
If you are a Stanford community member interested in attending a Senate meeting please contact Adrienne Emory at [aemory@stanford.edu](mailto:aemory@stanford.edu).
Agendas and Minutes, as they become available, can be viewed by clicking on the links in the table below.
| AUTUMN QUARTER | WINTER QUARTER | SPRING QUARTER |
|---|---|---|
AUTUMN QUARTER 10/09/25
| WINTER QUARTER 01/22/26Agenda Minutes | SPRING QUARTER 04/09/26Agenda Minutes |
AUTUMN QUARTER 10/23/25
| WINTER QUARTER 02/05/26Agenda Minutes | SPRING QUARTER 04/23/26Agenda Minutes |
AUTUMN QUARTER 11/06/25
| WINTER QUARTER 02/19/26Agenda Minutes | SPRING QUARTER 05/07/26Agenda Minutes |
AUTUMN QUARTER 11/20/25
| WINTER QUARTER 03/05/26Agenda Minutes | SPRING QUARTER 05/21/26Annual Academic Council MeetingAgenda Minutes |
| AUTUMN QUARTER | WINTER QUARTER | SPRING QUARTER 06/11/26Agenda Minutes |
Administrative Sessions of the Steering Committee on Behalf of the Senate
The Steering Committee (StC) holds administrative sessions as needed to hear routine or administrative matters that would otherwise come before the full Senate. This allows the Senate to spend more time on issues that need broader discussion and debate prior to action. All Senators are welcome to attend administrative sessions.

classification.reasoning: The page discusses Stanford's seven schools co-located on a single campus, emphasizing their academic excellence and interdisciplinary collaboration, which aligns with academic program descriptions.

extracted_info.summary: Stanford University's seven schools co-locate on one campus, fostering multidisciplinary collaboration. The Graduate School of Business focuses on developing global leaders through rigorous education and personal development.
key_points: Stanford has seven co-located schools with exceptional academic excellence
Multidisciplinary collaboration is facilitated by the campus layout
Graduate School of Business emphasizes leadership development and holistic education

metadata.title: Stanford’s Seven Schools
metadata.raw_text: Stanford is unique among its peer institutions in having seven schools co-located on one contiguous campus, and all of them possess exceptional breadth and depth of excellence. This naturally facilitates multidisciplinary collaboration. Graduate School of Business Stanford Graduate School of Business is developing the next generation of principled global leaders, delivering rigorous management education combined with personal development to change lives, change organizations, and change the world.

extracted_info.summary: Baxter实验室是斯坦福医学院的干细胞生物学研究机构，由Donald E.和Delia B. Baxter基金会资助，主任为Helen M. Blau博士，专注于利用生物系统治疗疾病的研究。
key_points: 实验室成立于2002年，由斯坦福医学院资助
主任为Helen M. Blau博士，教授干细胞生物学
研究领域包括心血管疾病、癌症、HIV、自身免疫病等的治疗
使用基因调控RNA和干细胞疗法开发新型药物

organizations: Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter基金会

contact_info.address: 269 Campus Drive, CCSR Building Room 4215, Stanford, California 94305-5175

metadata.title: Baxter Lab
metadata.raw_text:
The Baxter Laboratory for Stem Cell Biology The faculty of the Baxter Laboratory at the 2023 Baxter Retreat -- Professors Peter Jackson, Garry Nolan, and Helen Blau The Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Laboratory The Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Laboratory was created at Stanford University School of Medicine in January 2002. Helen M. Blau, Ph.D., of the department of Microbiology and Immunology and and the Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Professor of Stem Cell Biology is the first director of the Baxter Laboratory. The Laboratory has been made possible by an endowment provided to the school of medicine by the Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Foundation. The opening of the Baxter Laboratory was celebrated in May 2002. What the Baxter Laboratory is about The founding principles of the Baxter Laboratory are to bring together bioscientists who are interested not only in the basic mechanisms of disease processes, but also in exploiting biological systems to more directly bring about cures for important diseases. The laboratory also seeks to bring together researchers interested in similar diseases in a collaborative fashion. Research Research is conducted in the specific areas of blood vessel growth relevant to treatment of cardiac disease and cancer, HIV, autoimmune disease, adult stem cells, and genetic engineering. One focus is the genetic networks controlled by reguatory RNAs and the roles that these RNAs play in modulating the development, function and pathogenesis of vertebrate immune systems. Many of the approaches focus on enlisting the body to fight its own diseases - one recent example is the finding that cells from adult bone marrow can be recruited to rescue damaged tissues, such as adult brain cells which may be injured by stroke, Parkinson's disease, or by trauma to the head. Location Located on the top floor of the Sir Norman Foster designed Center for Clinical Sciences Research laboratory building at the School of Medicine, and adjacent to the Beckman Center for Molecular and Genetic Medicine, the laboratory uses innovative cellular, genetic, and pharmacological approaches for novel drug design and delivery in order to enhance cellular repair processes. Baxter Laboratory for Stem Cell Biology  |  Stanford University School of Medicine 
269 Campus Drive, CCSR Building Room 4215  |  Stanford, California 94305-5175  |  Phone: 650-723-6209
metadata.text:
The Baxter Laboratory for Stem Cell Biology
![Helen Blau, Garry Nolan, Peter Jackson Helen Blau, Garry Nolan, Peter Jackson](https://med.stanford.edu/baxterlab/_jcr_content/main/panel_builder/panel_0/image.img.476.high.jpg/headshot_smallGroup_0027.jpg)
The faculty of the Baxter Laboratory at the 2023 Baxter Retreat -- Professors Peter Jackson, Garry Nolan, and Helen Blau
The Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Laboratory
The Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Laboratory was created at Stanford University School of Medicine in January 2002. Helen M. Blau, Ph.D., of the department of Microbiology and Immunology and and the Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Professor of Stem Cell Biology is the first director of the Baxter Laboratory. The Laboratory has been made possible by an endowment provided to the school of medicine by the Donald E. and Delia B. Baxter Foundation. The opening of the Baxter Laboratory was celebrated in May 2002.
What the Baxter Laboratory is about
The founding principles of the Baxter Laboratory are to bring together bioscientists who are interested not only in the basic mechanisms of disease processes, but also in exploiting biological systems to more directly bring about cures for important diseases. The laboratory also seeks to bring together researchers interested in similar diseases in a collaborative fashion.
Research
Research is conducted in the specific areas of blood vessel growth relevant to treatment of cardiac disease and cancer, HIV, autoimmune disease, adult stem cells, and genetic engineering. One focus is the genetic networks controlled by reguatory RNAs and the roles that these RNAs play in modulating the development, function and pathogenesis of vertebrate immune systems. Many of the approaches focus on enlisting the body to fight its own diseases - one recent example is the finding that cells from adult bone marrow can be recruited to rescue damaged tissues, such as adult brain cells which may be injured by stroke, Parkinson's disease, or by trauma to the head.
![CCSR CCSR](https://med.stanford.edu/baxterlab/_jcr_content/main/panel_builder_1382857146/panel_0/panel_builder/panel_0/text_image.img.320.high.jpg/1461370510062.jpg)
Location
Located on the top floor of the Sir Norman Foster designed Center for Clinical Sciences Research laboratory building at the School of Medicine, and adjacent to the Beckman Center for Molecular and Genetic Medicine, the laboratory uses innovative cellular, genetic, and pharmacological approaches for novel drug design and delivery in order to enhance cellular repair processes.
Baxter Laboratory for Stem Cell Biology | Stanford University School of Medicine
269 Campus Drive, CCSR Building Room 4215 | Stanford, California 94305-5175 | Phone: 650-723-6209

classification.reasoning: The page discusses research programs, shared technology resources, and historical achievements in life sciences, aligning with academic_program categories related to interdisciplinary research and institutional facilities.

extracted_info.summary: Beckman Center致力于生命科学的创新、发现和领导，提供多学科科研平台和共享技术资源，推动基础科学与临床医学的结合，近期发布2025年度报告并更新细胞成像、PAN平台等科研设施。
key_points: 多学科科研平台：基础科学与转化应用并重
共享技术资源：4个高科技实验室服务斯坦福大学
历史成就：1970-1980年代基因工程、细胞成像等突破
最新动态：2025年度报告发布，新增细胞成像设施资源

metadata.title: Beckman Center
metadata.raw_text:
Beckman Center:
 Innovation, Discovery, and Leadership in the Life Sciences
	    
     Innovation, Discovery, and Leadership in the Life Sciences 
  
  
  
  Beckman Center Programs Our multidisciplinary programs promote discovery and innovation in the basic sciences and translation of discoveries into new diagnostic and therapeutic applications. The Service Centers The Beckman Center’s shared technology resources is comprised of four highly specialized scientific facilities that serve departments and laboratories throughout Stanford University. About Beckman Center The breakthroughs that took place in genetic engineering, cell imaging, and genomics in the late 1970s and ‘80s had a profound impact on the field of medicine, introducing new technologies and opening up new avenues for research in genetics and molecular biology. Since 1989, Beckman Center has promoted discovery and innovation in the basic sciences, accelerating the introduction and application of new technologies in basic science research and clinical medicine. News Keep informed about the latest Beckman Center news! Cell Sciences Imaging Facility Adds Resources to Help Researchers Use Bio-Atomic Force Microscopy > PAN’s MERSCOPE Platform Provides High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomics for Stanford Researchers > Wu Tsai Neurosciences Institute’s Neuroscience Microscopy Service Merges with the Beckman Center’s Cell Sciences Imaging Facility > The 2025 Annual Report is Here! Photo Credits: Christine Baker, Lotus Pod Designs, and Justin Lewis
metadata.text:
Beckman Center:
Innovation, Discovery, and Leadership in the Life Sciences
Beckman Center Programs
Our multidisciplinary programs promote discovery and innovation in the basic sciences and translation of discoveries into new diagnostic and therapeutic applications.
The Service Centers
The Beckman Center’s shared technology resources is comprised of four highly specialized scientific facilities that serve departments and laboratories throughout Stanford University.
About Beckman Center
The breakthroughs that took place in genetic engineering, cell imaging, and genomics in the late 1970s and ‘80s had a profound impact on the field of medicine, introducing new technologies and opening up new avenues for research in genetics and molecular biology.
Since 1989, Beckman Center has promoted discovery and innovation in the basic sciences, accelerating the introduction and application of new technologies in basic science research and clinical medicine.
News
Keep informed about the latest Beckman Center news!
[Cell Sciences Imaging Facility Adds Resources to Help Researchers Use Bio-Atomic Force Microscopy >](https://med.stanford.edu/beckman/news/csif-bioafm-fall-2024.html)[PAN’s MERSCOPE Platform Provides High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomics for Stanford Researchers >](https://med.stanford.edu/beckman/news/pan-merscope-fall-2024.html)[Wu Tsai Neurosciences Institute’s Neuroscience Microscopy Service Merges with the Beckman Center’s Cell Sciences Imaging Facility >](https://med.stanford.edu/beckman/news/csif-nms-fall-2024.html)
The 2025 Annual Report is Here!
Photo Credits: Christine Baker, Lotus Pod Designs, and Justin Lewis

metadata.title: Stanford AI Lab
metadata.author: Aishwarya Mandyam
metadata.raw_text: Stanford AI Lab The Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) has been a center of excellence for Artificial Intelligence research, teaching, theory, and practice since its founding in 1963. Latest News Carlos Guestrin named as new Director of the Stanford AI Lab! We thank Christopher Manning for being Director of the Stanford AI Lab during a period of enormous growth for AI and SAIL from 2018–2025 and today welcome Carlos Guestrin, Fortinet Founders Professor of Computer Science, as the new Director of SAIL. Congratulations to Prof. Fei-Fei Li for being one of the seven engineers who have made seminal contributions to the development of Modern Machine Learning awarded the 2025 Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering. Congratulations, Emma for being elected as AAAI Fellow! Congratulations to Chelsea Finn, Dorsa Sadigh, and Sanmi Koyejo for all winning a Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers (PECASE), the highest honor of the U.S. government for outstanding early career scientists and engineers. Congratulations to Sebastian Thrun for receiving honorary doctorate from Geogia Tech! Sebastian Thrun received an honorary Doctorate from Georgia Tech! This is Sebastian’s fourth honorary doctorate. Sebastian also served as a speaker for Georgia Tech’s Fall commencement ceremony Ellen Vitercik received a Schmidt Science 2024 AI2050 Early Career Fellow Award Tatsu Hashimoto and Shuran Song both received “Samsung AI Researcher of the Year” awards Congratulations to Stanford AI Lab PhD student Dora Zhao for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award! Congratulations to Stanford AI Lab PhD student Dora Zhao for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award for a paper from her work at Sony AI on: Measure Dataset Diversity, Don’t Just Claim It Congratulations to Aaron Lou, Chenlin Meng, and Stefano Ermon for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award! Congratulations to Aaron Lou, Chenlin Meng, and Stefano Ermon for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award: Discrete Diffusion Modeling by Estimating the Ratios of the Data Distribution Congratulations to Marco Pavone for a Robotics: Science and Systems Conference Best Paper Award! Congratulations to Marco Pavone for winning the best paper award at the Robotics: Science and Systems Conference on AI Safety for autonomous systems. Congratulations to Carlos Guestrin for being elected to the NAE! Carlos Guestrin has been elected to the National Academic of Engineering “for scalable systems and algorithms enabling the broad application of machine learning in science and industry.” Congratulations to Chris Manning on being awarded 2024 IEEE John von Neumann Medal! Chris Manning has been awarded the 2024 IEEE John von Neumann Medal “for advances in computational representation and analysis of natural language.” This is one of IEEE’s top awards in computing, given with very broad scope “for outstanding achievements in computer-related science and technology.” SAIL Faculty and Students Win NeurIPS Outstanding Paper Awards Congratulations to Sanmi Koyejo and his students for winning the NeurIPS Outstanding Paper Award, and congradulations to Chris Manning, Stefano Ermon, Chelsea Finn, and their students for winning Outstanding Paper Runner Up at NeurIPS! Prof. Fei Fei Li featured in CBS Mornings the Age of AI Follow Prof. Li's interview with CBS Mornings and on being named the "Godmother of AI" We Are Pleased to Welcome New Members of Our Faculty Diyi Yang who focuses on Computational Social Science and Natural Language Processing Sanmi Koyejo who focuses on Trustworthy Machine Learning for Healthcare and Neuroscience Affiliates Program Stanford AI Lab faculty and students enjoy chances to understand and solve the not-yet-doable pain points of industry. Get a chance to support and interact with SAIL’s brightest minds. Learn More
metadata.text:
Stanford AI Lab
The Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) has been a center of excellence for Artificial Intelligence research, teaching, theory, and practice since its founding in 1963.
![](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/John_McCarthy_Stanford-1.jpg)
![](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/sail_lab_051122_0153_hex.png)
![](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/hex-img-4.jpg)
![](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/B-CAM-2022SE-102_sm2.jpg)
![](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/sail_lab_oceanone_hex_5cred2.png)
Latest News
Carlos Guestrin named as new Director of the Stanford AI Lab!
We thank Christopher Manning for being Director of the Stanford AI Lab during a period of enormous growth for AI and SAIL from 2018–2025 and today welcome Carlos Guestrin, Fortinet Founders Professor of Computer Science, as the new Director of SAIL.
Congratulations to Prof. Fei-Fei Li for being one of the seven engineers who have made seminal contributions to the development of Modern Machine Learning awarded the 2025 Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering.
Congratulations, Emma for being elected as AAAI Fellow!
Congratulations to Chelsea Finn, Dorsa Sadigh, and Sanmi Koyejo for all winning a Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers (PECASE), the highest honor of the U.S. government for outstanding early career scientists and engineers.
Congratulations to Sebastian Thrun for receiving honorary doctorate from Geogia Tech!
Sebastian Thrun received an honorary Doctorate from Georgia Tech! This is Sebastian’s fourth honorary doctorate. Sebastian also served as a speaker for Georgia Tech’s Fall commencement ceremony
Ellen Vitercik received a Schmidt Science 2024 AI2050 Early Career Fellow Award
Tatsu Hashimoto and Shuran Song both received “Samsung AI Researcher of the Year” awards
Congratulations to Stanford AI Lab PhD student Dora Zhao for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award!
Congratulations to Stanford AI Lab PhD student Dora Zhao for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award for a paper from her work at Sony AI on: Measure Dataset Diversity, Don’t Just Claim It
Congratulations to Aaron Lou, Chenlin Meng, and Stefano Ermon for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award!
Congratulations to Aaron Lou, Chenlin Meng, and Stefano Ermon for an ICML 2024 Best Paper Award: Discrete Diffusion Modeling by Estimating the Ratios of the Data Distribution
Congratulations to Marco Pavone for a Robotics: Science and Systems Conference Best Paper Award!
Congratulations to Marco Pavone for winning the best paper award at the Robotics: Science and Systems Conference on AI Safety for autonomous systems.
Congratulations to Carlos Guestrin for being elected to the NAE!
Carlos Guestrin has been elected to the National Academic of Engineering “for scalable systems and algorithms enabling the broad application of machine learning in science and industry.”
Congratulations to Chris Manning on being awarded 2024 IEEE John von Neumann Medal!
Chris Manning has been awarded the 2024 IEEE John von Neumann Medal “for advances in computational representation and analysis of natural language.” This is one of IEEE’s top awards in computing, given with very broad scope “for outstanding achievements in computer-related science and technology.”
SAIL Faculty and Students Win NeurIPS Outstanding Paper Awards
Congratulations to Sanmi Koyejo and his students for winning the NeurIPS Outstanding Paper Award, and congradulations to Chris Manning, Stefano Ermon, Chelsea Finn, and their students for winning Outstanding Paper Runner Up at NeurIPS!
Prof. Fei Fei Li featured in CBS Mornings the Age of AI
Follow Prof. Li's interview with CBS Mornings and on being named the "Godmother of AI"
We Are Pleased to Welcome New Members of Our Faculty
Diyi Yang who focuses on Computational Social Science and Natural Language Processing
Sanmi Koyejo who focuses on Trustworthy Machine Learning for Healthcare and Neuroscience
![Ludwig Schmidt](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Ludwig_Schmidt_HOME2.jpg)
![Yejin Choi](https://ai.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Yejin_Choi_SAIL.jpg)
Affiliates Program
Stanford AI Lab faculty and students enjoy chances to understand and solve the not-yet-doable pain points of industry. Get a chance to support and interact with SAIL’s brightest minds.
[Learn More](http://ai.stanford.edu/ai-affiliates-program/)
![back to top](/wp-content/themes/sail/img/top-button.png)

extracted_info.summary: Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) 2025年12月举办AI+HEALTH虚拟会议，主任Curtis Langlotz提出AI将取代不使用AI的放射科医生，会议包含AIMI Grand Rounds等临床AI应用研讨。
key_points: AIMI 2025年12月9-10日举办第5届AI+HEALTH虚拟会议（CME认证）
AIMI Grand Rounds 2025年12月16日由Dr. Eric Yang主讲，主题为AI在手部神经外科的应用
主任Curtis Langlotz 2017年提出'AI取代不使用AI的放射科医生'双关语

organizations: Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging

contact_info.address: Stanford University, 300 Campus Drive, Stanford, CA 94305

metadata.title: Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging
metadata.raw_text: Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging Director's Welcome Back in 2017, I tweeted “radiologists who use AI will replace radiologists who don’t.” The tweet has taken on a life of its own, perhaps because it has a double meaning. Stanford AI+HEALTH Virtual Conference Join us this December 9-10, 2025, for our 5th annual AI+HEALTH virtual conference! The CME-accredited program will focus on clinical AI applications in use today, integrating AI into healthcare settings, and pioneering innovations in health AI. AIMI Grand Rounds - December 16, 2025 Join us on Tuesday, December 16, at 8:00 AM PT for the next AIMI Grand Rounds with Dr. Eric Yang, moderated by Dr. Alex Dussaq. RSVP here
metadata.text:
Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging
![Curtis Langlotz](/sites/g/files/sbiybj20451/files/styles/responsive_large/public/media/image/director_curt_2020_0.jpeg?itok=23xSE5Ek)
Director's Welcome
Back in 2017, I tweeted “radiologists who use AI will replace radiologists who don’t.” The tweet has taken on a life of its own, perhaps because it has a double meaning.
![](/sites/g/files/sbiybj20451/files/styles/card_1900x950/public/media/image/aihealth25_graphic_v3_0.png?h=c9f93661&itok=Ma8iZGk4)
Stanford AI+HEALTH Virtual Conference
Join us this December 9-10, 2025, for our 5th annual AI+HEALTH virtual conference! The CME-accredited program will focus on clinical AI applications in use today, integrating AI into healthcare settings, and pioneering innovations in health AI.
AIMI Grand Rounds - December 16, 2025
Join us on Tuesday, December 16, at 8:00 AM PT for the next AIMI Grand Rounds with Dr. Eric Yang, moderated by Dr. Alex Dussaq.
[RSVP here](https://stanford.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_CJvCtPBqQzWM2P8I4hahIA)
